occasions.name: Test Occasion Week
occasions.factoid: This is a test occasion. If you can see purple accents and a custom icon in the theme button, everything is working correctly.

occasions.name: National Cherry Blossom Festival
occasions.factoid: The original 3,000 cherry trees planted along the Tidal Basin were a gift from Tokyo Mayor Yukio Ozaki in 1912 — offered without intellectual property conditions of any kind.

occasions.name: Oktoberfest
occasions.factoid: Oktoberfest has been held on Munich's Theresienwiese since 1810, originally to celebrate Crown Prince Ludwig's wedding to Princess Therese of Saxony-Hildburghausen.

occasions.name: World IP Day
occasions.factoid: World Intellectual Property Day has been observed on April 26th since 2001 — the date the WIPO Convention entered into force in 1970.

occasions.name: Constitution Day
occasions.factoid: Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution explicitly grants Congress power to protect intellectual property — one of the few areas of law the founders named directly.

occasions.name: German Unity Day
occasions.factoid: On October 3rd 1990, East and West Germany officially reunified. The combined patent portfolio of East German state enterprises presented one of the largest IP integration challenges in European history.

factoids.text: Benjamin Franklin was born on January 17, 1706. He never patented any of his inventions, believing they should be freely shared.
Thomas Edison was born on February 11, 1847. He holds 1,093 US patents — still the record for an individual inventor.
On February 23, 1893, Rudolf Diesel received German patent DE67207 for his rational heat engine — what we now call the diesel engine.
Alexander Graham Bell received US Patent 174,465 for the telephone on March 7, 1876 — one of the most contested and valuable patents ever granted.
The first US Patent Act was signed into law by George Washington on April 10, 1790. The first patent was issued just three months later.
On June 15, 1752, Benjamin Franklin conducted his famous kite experiment demonstrating lightning's electrical nature — but famously filed no patent.
US Independence Day. The Continental Congress met in Philadelphia's State House — the same city where the first US patent office operated.
Thomas Edison demonstrated the first practical incandescent light bulb on October 22, 1879. US Patent 223,898 followed the next year.
The Wright Brothers made their first powered flight on December 17, 1903. Their patent battle with Glenn Curtiss defined aviation IP law for decades.
The USPTO remains closed on Christmas Day. Patent deadlines falling today automatically shift to the next business day.
